title: Machine Learning Helps Constrain the Thickness of Ancient Crust

last_post.content:
Machine Learning Helps Constrain the Thickness of Ancient Crust
A machine learning model trained using data on the chemical composition of magmatic rocks yields comparable, if not better, results to previously developed geochemical proxies.
https://eos.org/editor-highlights/machine-learning-helps-constrain-the-thickness-of-ancient-crust #MachineLearning #ancient #crust #tectonics

title: Postal codes in the Netherlands - Wikipedia

last_post.content:
10/ Final point - the Netherlands 🇳🇱 is one of the few countries in the world to use alphanumeric postcodes.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postal_codes_in_the_Netherlands

Dutch postcodes also contain a space, thus breaking many assumptions software developers have about postcodes!

See our guide:
https://opencagedata.com/guides/how-to-think-about-postcodes-and-geocoding

3/ to make things more confusing though, the Netherlands 🇳🇱 includes "the Caribbean Netherlands" 🇧🇶, made up of three "special municipalities": Bonaire, Sint Eustatius, and Saba

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Netherlands

This makes NL one of only a few "multi-continental" countries, and thus a correct answer in our Feb 2021 #fridaygeotrivia contest

https://blog.opencagedata.com/post/geotrivia-feb2021-multicontinent-countries

Tengo que decir que la aplicación de Pidetaxi, creada por y para los taxistas en España, ha mejorado mucho en los últimos años, me ha funcionado perfectamente en dos ciudades, y me han atendido taxistas majísimos. Ya he dejado de usar FreeNow después de muchos años (desde que era MyTaxi). Si sois asiduos os animo aprobarla, y por supuesto si estáis usando Uber y Cabify no tenéis excusa para pasaros a un servicio que respeta los derechos de los trabajadores.

https://pidetaxi.es

#taxi

title: How might adding search change Mastodon?

last_post.content:
Good question about online conversations: "Is the discourse predominantly friendly or hostile? What kinds of community norms govern interactions?"
https://write.as/ulrikehahn/how-might-adding-search-change-mastodon

Spread of emotions on a social networks require certain level of visibility to reactions of other people. But if a system is designed to limit visibility, contagion effect is potentially smaller.

But how do people see the reactions if they only see the text output, not the other expressions of emotional reactions?

Hey it’s #PitchYaGame day!

My latest project is Souvenirs, a role-playing game for one player about going on a week-long vacation and writing a journal of the places you visit & the items you collect as souvenirs of your trips. It’s an introspective, nostalgic, laid-back game that has been very warmly received by players and that will get a nice visual update next week (plus a french translation)!

Get it on @itchio: https://remi-tootata.itch.io/souvenirs

Every geo/GIS job in Australia is an ESRI job.

If you want to avoid capture of an entire sector and de-risk your stuff, not to mention save buckets of ongoing $$ just to use software, get in touch.

I can design an open source / open data strategy - field data collection, drone mapping, data infrastructure. And because of standards it will still talk ESRI if you really want it to.

Example from 2020 here: https://figshare.com/articles/preprint/ASDC_-_Enabling_PointsDC_-_APPF_pdf/12799970

I've experienced decades of being dehumanised and deprioritised for being on a bicycle. I've seen years of UK columnists/media dehumanising people on bikes. I've pointed out that "safety" clothing doesn't have strong evidence for being safer (and requirements for helmets disuade people getting on bikes). I've observed that drivers who also cycle are generally more considerate and better around bikes. And I've observed that close-passing laws can change driver behaviors https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1369847823001018

“SHALL WE PLAY A GAME?” It was 40 years ago today, on June 3, 1983, when “War Games” was released in the US, giving us all a taste then of the dangers of giving full control to #AI systems. Watching the trailer now, it’s fun to hear all the modem sounds and everything else:

https://youtu.be/TQUsLAAZuhU

(More about the film: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WarGames )

I was in high school at the time, and was dialing into BBS’s and services, so I absolutely loved the film. 40 years!!!

#WarGames

The US #CopyrightOffice reiterates the rule that the "author" of a copyrightable work must be a human being, and tries to clarify the ways in which authors may use #AI tools to assist in producing copyrightable work. https://www.copyright.gov/ai/ai_policy_guidance.pdf

For example, an author "may modify material originally generated by AI technology to such a degree that the modifications meet the standard for copyright protection."

title: K366.7. Thieving butterflies (WTF - Weird Things in Folktales)

last_post.content:
I didn't even know it was #ButterflyAwarenessDay, and yet I was telling butterfly folktales at an online #storytelling session 😄 🦋 🦋 🦋

I love it when things just align like that!

I told the story of the Thieving Butterflies from the Cook Islands, where butterflies use their mimicry to steal back a swordfish stolen from a deity by an eight-headed lizard.

Read here:
http://multicoloreddiary.blogspot.com/2017/04/k3667-thieving-butterflies-wtf-weird.html

#folklore #folktales

For Butterfly Awareness & Education Day:
Papalotl (#butterflies ) in Book 11 of the Florentine Codex ("Earthly Things,” the volume dedicated primarily to #Aztec natural history). All illustrations done by #Indigenous #Nahua artists; the 12-volume encyclopedia was compiled by Spanish Franciscan friar Bernardino de Sahagún & completed c. 1577.
See images in original text here:
https://www.loc.gov/resource/gdcwdl.wdl_10622/?sp=6&st=gallery
#ButterflyDay #IndigenousArt #Mesoamerica #ColonialArt

Anonymizing peer review makes the process more just https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-023-01772-w

Disappointing (but perhaps not surprising) to see this evidence of prestige bias.

However, while one may argue that anonymization makes peer review more just, I'd argue it also inhibits normal ways of communicating between researchers. I see this as major drawback!

I think peer review can also be made more just by moving away from accept/reject decisions, and this has the benefit that it doesn't require anonymization.

title: Texas Bill to Increase Transparency in Public Records Law Left in Limbo Despite Passing Legislature

last_post.content:
Texas Bill to Increase Transparency in Public Records Law Left in Limbo Despite Passing Legislature
==

#Texas lawmakers passed more than 1,300 bills before the end of this year’s contentious legislative session, quickly sending them to Gov. #GregAbbott for consideration.

All of them but one.

A bill that would close a long-standing loophole in state law that allows officials to withhold law enforcement records if no one was convicted in a case.

#Transparency

Just read that John Aaron, the “Steely- eyed missile man” shown in the movie as fixing the CO2 scrubbers, was actually the guy who devised the diabolical power-up sequence. https://www.ruso.edu/single-post/john-aaron-nasa-engineer#:~:text=Among%20his%20many%20contributions%2C%20Aaron,steely%2Deyed%20missile%20man.%E2%80%9D

This whole thread is great, but I think we also need to think hard about what to do when corporations do get governmental (or even supergovernmental) power. The fact that this has happened is, in my opinion, a big problem. Corporations like Google and Facebook do have government sized control over speech, far less accountability, and their sheer scale distorts the compensating social processes so far beyond what those systems would ordinarily handle.

They also have hegemonic power.

https://hachyderm.io/@inthehands/110481879199090514

"What Makes a Data-GIF Understandable?" https://arxiv.org/pdf/2008.07227.pdf "While other storytelling formats such as data videos, infographics, or data comics are relatively well studied, we have little knowledge about the design factors and principles for “data-GIFs”. To close this gap, we provide results from semi-structured interviews and an online study with a total of 118 participants investigating the impact of design decisions on the understandability of data-GIFs."

title: Mystery Behind the Sailing Stones of Death Valley

last_post.content:
These are the “sliding rocks” or “sailing stones” of Death Valley. First documented by miners back in the 1900s, these rocks range from pebbles to 600-pound (272-kilogram) boulders and seem to move of their own accord. The only evidence of their activity is a series of long, perplexing trails left in the valley’s dried mud.
By #GeologyWonders
#Geology #GeologyPage #Nature #minerals #crystals #gems #Nature #NatureLovers #NaturePhotography #Photographer
https://www.geologyin.com/2017/07/death-valleys-moving-rocks.html?fbclid=IwAR0Pb7D_I6v_mTYDz_1Hkggu7A8EX3pwIbaVAKgG9gRvRXXeH8Mr8kQkWkI

title: Hunger strike and high school graduation: A visit to The Forty Acres

last_post.content:
New post from Delano CA: Who goes for graduation pictures at the site of a hunger strike? The sight of Daniella, Mariah, and their families stepping out of their cars in their graduation caps and gowns completely transformed my understanding of a site I had only seen in history books.

https://globalvoices.org/2023/06/03/hunger-strike-and-high-school-graduation-a-visit-to-the-forty-acres/
